layman:
**Reason for Evaluation**  
The patient is a 37‑year‑old white single man who was admitted to the hospital from the emergency room. I saw him in my office the day before and told him to go to the hospital. He had just returned from a trip to Tahoe, Nevada, where he had thoughts of killing his mother. He was scared by these thoughts and called me over the weekend. We were able to see him on Tuesday after talking to him.

**History of Present Illness**  
He has had a chronic psychotic illness for many years. He started having auditory and visual hallucinations and paranoid thoughts when he was about 18 or 19. He used drugs and smoked marijuana at that time and tried other drugs. He stopped using drugs at age 25 but still has frequent, intense psychotic episodes. I have seen him for about a year. He has not responded well to treatment. We have tried many medication combinations, including Clozaril, Risperdal, lithium, and Depakote. The response has been only temporary, usually lasting a few days. We have used very high doses: Clozaril 1200 mg, Risperdal up to 9 mg, and lithium at a therapeutic level, but he has not improved. He has delusions that the Antichrist is real, that neighborhood dogs are talking to him and criticizing him, and that all people and animals can communicate with him telepathically. He also has had homicidal thoughts before this admission.

**Past Psychiatric History**  
He has had psychotic episodes for about 20 years. He has sometimes improved on Clozaril and other medications, but the improvement is temporary. With typical antipsychotics he has done well at times, but he eventually has another psychotic episode.

**Past Medical History**  
He has obesity and diabetes. He has not been treated for diabetes recently because he stopped taking Zyprexa. He also has chronic bronchitis. He smokes up to 60 cigarettes a day.

**Drug History**  
He stopped using drugs at age 25 and has stayed clean for more than 10 years. He still smokes heavily, which is a problem for his health because of his chronic bronchitis.

**Psychosocial Status**  
He lives with his mother and has been staying with her for a few years. She is very supportive. His only sister is also supportive. He has lived in the ABCD houses in the past and did poorly in some of them.

**Mental Status Examination**  
He was alert and oriented to time, place, and person. His affect was flat. He talked about hearing voices, which were unclear. He is not homicidal in the hospital, unlike when he was at home. His voice and speech were normal. He believes in telepathy. His memory is intact and his intelligence is average.

**Initial Diagnoses**  
- Axis I: Schizophrenia  
- Axis II: Deferred  
- Axis III: Diabetes, obesity, chronic bronchitis  
- Axis IV: Moderate  
- Axis V: GAF 35 on admission  

**Initial Treatment and Plan**  
Because he has been on very high medication doses, we will give him a break and a structured environment. We will give him benzodiazepines and decide on an antipsychotic later. We will make sure he is safe and that his medical needs are addressed.
